context.text: Taylor in [5] proved that a memory has an associated information storage capacity, \$C\$, such that arbitrarily reliable information storage is possible for all memory redundancies greater than \$1/C\$.
Taylor [5] considered two models of component failures and proposed construction of fault-tolerant memories based on low-density parity-check (LDPC) codes.
A memory is a device in which information is stored at some time and retrieved at a later time [5].
Hence, to ensure reliable storage, the information needs to be stored in coded form (see [5] for an excellent discussion on the importance of coded form).

The complexity of a memory is the number of components within the memory (a component is a device which either performs an elementary operation or stores a single bit where an elementary operation is any Boolean function of two binary operands [5]).
The storage capacity, \$C\$, of a memory is a number such that for all memory redundancies greater than \$1/C\$, arbitrarily reliable information storage is possible [5].
Taylor in [5] argues that no decoding scheme other than iterative decoding of LDPC codes can achieve non-zero storage capacity.

context.text: In 1999, Jiménez Felström and Zigangirov proposed low density parity check convolutional codes (LDPC-CCs) [3].
Further-more, LDPC-CCs have a simpler encoder algorithm, and a hardware decoder can be implemented conveniently in silicon by a cascade of physically identical processors [3].

context.text: Relevance vector machine (RVM)-based regression and classification have been proposed in [15]–[17].
The advantages of the RVM over the SVM are probabilistic predictions, automatic estimations of parameters, and the possibility of choosing arbitrary kernel functions [15], [16].

Given a set of \$N\$ corresponding training pairs \$\{{\bf x}_{n}, t_{n}\}_{n = 1}^{N}\$, the objective is to find values for the weights \${\bf w} = (w_{1}, w_{2}, \ldots, w_{M})^{T}\$, such that \$y({\bf x})\$ generalizes well enough to new data, yet only a few elements of \${\bf w}\$ are nonzero [15].

Although the SVM classification provides successful results, a number of significant and practical disadvantages are identified as [15], [16] follows.


•
Although SVMs are relatively sparse, the number of SVs typically grows linearly with the size of the training set, and therefore, SVMs make unnecessarily liberal use of basis functions.

•
Predictions are not probabilistic, and therefore, SVM is not suitable for classification tasks in which posterior probabilities of class membership are necessary.

•
In SVM, it is required to estimate the error/margin tradeoff parameter \$C\$, which generally entails a cross-validation procedure which can be a waste of data as well as computation.

•
In SVM, the kernel function must satisfy Mercer's condition; hence, it must be a continuous symmetric kernel of a positive integral operator.
The RVM has been introduced by Tipping [15], [16] as a Bayesian treatment alternative to the SVM that does not suffer from the aforementioned limitations.
The iteratively reweighed least-squares algorithm [15], [19] can be used to find \${ \bf w}_{\rm MP}\$.
For large data sets, this makes training considerably slower than SVM [15].

The algorithm in [5] exploits the multicomponent transformation (MCT) feature of JPEG 2000 Part 2 [6] to take advantage of the spectral correlation present in hyperspectral images.

The results are compared with those achieved by the scheme in [5] that employs the spectral KLT, followed by JPEG 2000 (i.e., the proposed scheme with no anomaly detection), and with a similar scheme that employs a spectral wavelet transform, followed by JPEG 2000 [9].

However, it has been shown in [5] that a significant computational saving can be obtained by not using all the spectral vectors, with a minor performance decrease.

Once a covert channel has been identified the generally available countermeasures are [98]:
•Eliminate the channel•Limit the bandwidth of the channel•Audit the channel•Document the channel
 According to Jeng et al. there are two causes of covert channels: design oversights and weaknesses inherent in the system design [98].

The parameter \$r_{C}\$ was extracted from the statistical spread of retention lifetimes, shown in Fig. 2, which is controlled by the size of crystalline particles relative to the thickness of the amorphous volume [20], [21].

Since the crystalline grain size at retention failure controls the statistics of \$t_{X}\$ [21], the evaluation of \$r_{C}\$ is useful for predicting the statistical spread of retention lifetime, e.g., as a function of scaling, temperature, and material properties.
